newsitem.title: FRANCE: French centre-right floats "dream-team" before vote.
newsitem.headline: French centre-right floats "dream-team" before vote.

text.p: France's ruling centre-right on Wednesday floated an unlikely-sounding "dream team" to salvage its chances in Sunday's parliamentary election runoff as the opposition Socialists savoured the prospect of victory.

French financial markets plunged on worries that the Socialist-led opposition, planning to create 700,000 jobs and cut working hours, would win Sunday's decisive ballot after taking a stunning first round lead.
Stocks plunged by 3.63 percent, the franc fell below a key level of 3.38 per mark and bonds also closed down.

Socially-minded Philippe Seguin, a former opponent of a single European currency, and militant free-marketeer Alain Madelin attended a rally together as the fractious centre-right thrust them into the limelight as seemingly improbable saviours.

"The president has said that we must find how to reconcile liberty and solidarity," National Assembly speaker Seguin, with Madelin alongside, told the rally of about 1,500 supporters in the Alpine city of Chambery.

He said that his views that more should be done for the poor and unemployed were "fully complementary" with the harsh deregulation favoured by Madelin, sacked as finance minister in 1995 for attacking civil servants' "privileges".
President Jacques Chirac telephoned both men to discuss the campaign in a veiled blessing of their alliance, bringing together opposite tendencies in the centre-right coalition.
Seguin has long been shown by opinion polls to be favourite as prime minister if the centre-right wins. Madelin could be finance minister.

Opposition Socialist leader Lionel Jospin, meanwhile, sounded increasingly confident. Chirac called the election 10 months early, wrongly believing the re-election of his coalition allies for another five years was a virtual formality.

"Yes, we are ready to govern," Jospin said in Cintegabelle, southwest France. And in a jab at Chirac's gamble gone awry, he said: "One must never be fooled by who is in charge. And in democracy, there is only one sovereign -- the people."
At a final cabinet meeting in Paris before the election, Chirac warned voters that change brings risks.
"France cannot afford to change direction all the time without taking serious risks," Chirac said.
To change horses now would lead to "confusion and weakness", government spokesman Alain Lamassoure quoted him as saying.
Jospin urged Chirac to brace for a period of power sharing with the left but also warned his followers against overconfidence, "even if victory seems more and more likely."

The left-wing opposition outpolled the centre-right coalition by more than four points in last Sunday's first round of voting. Polling firms said it was on course for a narrow majority if the pattern were repeated in next Sunday's runoff.

The sudden focus on Seguin and Madelin followed Prime Minister Alain Juppe's announcement on Monday that he was bowing out irrespective of Sunday's results, hoping to bolster the centre-right's chances in the final stretch.
Madelin took a swipe at the likely inclusion of Communists in any left-wing government.

"I know that (Communist party leader) Robert Hue seems more like Groucho Marx than Stalin, but people mustn't underestimate the consequences of a return of Socialo-Communism for our country," he told the magazine Valeurs Actuelles.
Seeking to lure back disenchanted voters, Chirac said in a televised message on Tuesday that he had heard their message but urged them not to return to "the socialist ideas of yesteryear".
Most analysts said his appeal fell short.
"Is that all there is?" headlined the daily France-Soir over a picture of Chirac in a Superman costume.
